key: _gpt-5__What is the extent of the evidence for the effectiveness of large-scale habitat restoration or creation on wild bee populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The average abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on field margins was positively correlated with the number of pollen and nectar agri-environment agreements within a 10 km grid square.
[Statement 2]: In one trial, 6 meter margins on uncropped grassy fields enhanced wild bee abundance but not diversity at field boundaries.
[Statement 3]: In another trial, 6 meter margins on uncropped grassy fields enhanced both wild bee abundance and diversity within the margin.
[Statement 4]: A smaller-scale trial detected no increase in wild bee abundance or diversity on sown grassy margins compared to cropped margins.
[Statement 5]: Fourteen trials in Europe and North America recorded substantial numbers of wild bees foraging on sown flowering plants.
[Statement 6]: Ten trials using the plant phacelia generally found substantial numbers of foraging wild bees, especially bumblebees.
[Statement 7]: One replicated trial in Greece found the plant phacelia was not very attractive to wild bees.
[Statement 8]: Six trials reported observing between 8 and 35 foraging bee species on sown flowering plants.
[Statement 9]: One replicated trial found that planted perennial leguminous herbs were more attractive to bumblebees in more arable landscapes.
[Statement 10]: One trial showed enhanced reproductive success of the bee species Osmia lignaria in orchards that had lupine patches.
[Statement 11]: One trial showed no increase in bee numbers or richness at distances of 50 to 1,500 meters from planted patches.
[Statement 12]: Two trials found no or few solitary bees nesting on set-aside fields that were sown with phacelia or clover.
[Statement 13]: For wild honey bees, there is no evidence on the impacts of reduced honey-hunting or improved harvesting on populations.
[Statement 14]: One trial in southern Vietnam reported over 85% occupancy of artificial rafters by the honey bee species Apis dorsata when the rafters were placed by a clearing larger than 25 meters in diameter.

[Statement 1]: Two replicated European trials reported higher numbers and diversity of wild bees on meadows with a delayed first cut and little agrochemical use.
[Statement 2]: Two trials found no difference in wild bee populations on meadows with reduced fertilizer or cutting intensity when compared to conventional meadows.
[Statement 3]: The evidence for the effect of reduced tillage or no-till farming on ground-nesting bees is mixed.
[Statement 4]: One replicated US study on squash farms found three times more squash bees on no-till farms.
[Statement 5]: Another study found no difference in bee abundance between tilled and untilled farms.
[Statement 6]: The evidence for the benefits of converting to organic arable farming for wild bees is equivocal.
[Statement 7]: Three replicated trials found higher wild bee abundance under organic management.
[Statement 8]: One trial showed higher bee diversity in organic wheat fields and adjacent mown fallow strips.
[Statement 9]: Three replicated trials found no significant differences for bumblebee numbers or species under organic management.
[Statement 10]: Three replicated trials found no significant differences for wild bees visiting flowering crops on organic farms.

key: _gpt-5__What actions related to reducing farming intensity can be taken to benefit wild bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across Europe, agri‑environment schemes have shown mixed outcomes for wild bees.
[Statement 2]: Four replicated trials reported enhanced diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees under schemes like the Swiss Ecological Compensation Areas and the Scottish Rural Stewardship Scheme.
[Statement 3]: Four other replicated trials found no enhancement for wild bees under schemes such as meadow bird agreements in Dutch wet grassland and 6-meter grass margin strips in England.
[Statement 4]: At landscape scales in the UK, two replicated trials found bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland with agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 5]: Agri-environment schemes in the UK resulted in no improvement in Bombus terrestris colony reproduction and no increase in spring queen numbers in two replicated trials.
[Statement 6]: A UK study found that agri-environment scheme prescriptions had local but not landscape‑scale effects on bee numbers.
[Statement 7]: Evidence for the effects of organic farming on wild bees is equivocal.
[Statement 8]: Three replicated trials in Europe or Canada found a higher abundance of wild bees under organic arable farming.
[Statement 9]: One trial reported higher bee diversity in organic wheat fields and adjacent mown fallow strips.
[Statement 10]: Three replicated trials in Europe or the USA found no significant differences in bumblebee numbers between organic and conventional farms.
[Statement 11]: Three replicated trials in Europe or the USA found no significant differences in bumblebee species richness between organic and conventional farms.
[Statement 12]: Replicated trials in Europe or the USA found no significant differences in wild bee visitation to crops between organic and conventional farms.

key: _gpt-5__What are the observed effects of implementing system-wide changes like agri-environment schemes or converting to organic farming for wild bees in Europe?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating patches of bare ground provides nesting habitat for ground-nesting solitary bees.
[Statement 2]: Patches of bare ground created for bee nesting were successfully colonized within one to two years in multiple trials.
[Statement 3]: Reducing or eliminating tillage can support ground-nesting bees.
[Statement 4]: One study found three times more squash bees on no-till farms, while another study found no difference.
[Statement 5]: Increasing areas of rough grassland or establishing grassy field margins provides nesting habitat for bumblebees.
[Statement 6]: Areas of rough grassland and grassy field margins attracted nest-searching queen bumblebees at higher densities than other compared habitats.
[Statement 7]: Providing artificial nest sites or nest boxes can support solitary bees.
[Statement 8]: Artificial nest sites for solitary bees show high uptake across many species.
[Statement 9]: Effective designs for artificial solitary bee nests include bundles of hollow stems or drilled wooden blocks.
[Statement 10]: It is recommended to place artificial nest boxes for solitary bees within 150 to 600 meters of forage.
[Statement 11]: The provision of artificial nest sites has been associated with increased local bee populations in some studies.
[Statement 12]: Bumblebee nest boxes have been tested but show a very low uptake rate of about 2% or less.
[Statement 13]: Introducing nest boxes already stocked with solitary bees is an option.
[Statement 14]: There is currently no evidence regarding the effects of introducing nest boxes stocked with solitary bees on farmland wildlife.

key: _gpt-5__Besides planting floral resources, what alternative habitat modifications can provide nesting sites for different types of bees on farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Documented risks and negative outcomes of reintroducing laboratory-reared bumblebee colonies include high rates of social parasitism.
[Statement 2]: Replicated trials have reported 25–66% and 79% parasitism in some releases of laboratory-reared bumblebee colonies.
[Statement 3]: Some UK trials involving reintroduced bumblebee colonies have resulted in cases of very low or zero queen production.
[Statement 4]: Supplementary feeding of reintroduced bumblebee colonies did not reduce the parasite load.
[Statement 5]: Supplementary feeding of reintroduced bumblebee colonies sometimes did not increase productivity.
[Statement 6]: For artificial nest sites for solitary bees, multiple trials have recorded attacks by parasites and predators.
[Statement 7]: In one species, measured mortality and parasitism in artificial nest sites for solitary bees ranged from 2% of brood cells attacked to 56% overall mortality.
[Statement 8]: Certain nest materials, such as plastic-lined holes, plastic tubes, or paper tubes, were less productive due to parasitism or mould.
[Statement 9]: Introduced European earwigs and non-native European leafcutter bees commonly occupied artificial nest boxes.
[Statement 10]: Introduced European earwigs and non-native European leafcutter bees sometimes occupied artificial nest boxes more than native bees did.
[Statement 11]: One trial recorded that bees made no use of the provided artificial nest boxes.
[Statement 12]: Nest boxes for bees have shown very low uptake by bumblebees, at a rate of 2% or less.
[Statement 13]: The low uptake of nest boxes by bumblebees limits the boxes' effectiveness.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented risks or negative impacts associated with interventions like providing artificial nests or reintroducing bee colonies?
_gpt-5__What are the most effective interventions for providing nesting resources for different types of wild bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Solitary bees commonly occupy artificial nest sites.
[Statement 2]: Replicated trials across multiple regions reported occupancy of artificial nests by solitary bees.
[Statement 3]: Artificial nests for solitary bees include cut hollow stems, tubes, and drilled wooden blocks.
[Statement 4]: Some endangered bee species and oil-collecting Centris species used artificial nests.
[Statement 5]: Occupancy of solitary bee nest boxes was readily observed across ten studies.
[Statement 6]: Reported occupancy rates for solitary bee nest boxes were 1–26% of cavities.
[Statement 7]: Between 4.6 and 33 bee species were recorded using solitary bee nest boxes.
[Statement 8]: The number of occupied solitary bee nests can double over three years with repeated nest box provision at a site.
[Statement 9]: Fields with nest boxes saw increased estimated numbers of foraging Osmia bees compared to fields without boxes.
[Statement 10]: The local population size of emerging red mason bees increased when nest boxes were provided in two replicated studies.
[Statement 11]: Effective designs and materials for solitary bee nests include cut stems, tubes, and drilled wood.
[Statement 12]: Reed stems and grooved-board nest boxes produced more bees per nest than several other types of nests.
[Statement 13]: Plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes were less productive for solitary bees due to parasitism or mould.
[Statement 14]: A replicated study found the highest production of red mason bees per nest was from reed stems or wood.
[Statement 15]: The placement of artificial nests near forage resources is important for solitary bees.
[Statement 16]: Four European bee species had foraging ranges of 150 to 600 meters, implying nests should be placed within this distance of forage.
[Statement 17]: One study recommended placing nest boxes 150 to 600 meters from forage.
[Statement 18]: Parasites and predators frequently attack the occupants of artificial bee nests, with mortality reported in multiple trials.
[Statement 19]: Introduced species and earwigs sometimes occupy artificial bee nest boxes.
[Statement 20]: Soil-filled boxes intended for a ground-nesting Andrena bee were not used.
[Statement 21]: Bumblebees showed very low uptake of artificial nest boxes.
[Statement 22]: Two replicated trials on bumblebees reported an occupancy rate of 2% or less for artificial nest boxes.
[Statement 23]: Stingless bees showed no uptake of the tested artificial nest boxes.
[Statement 24]: A replicated trial with the stingless bee Melipona quadrifasciata found no use of tree-placed nest boxes.
[Statement 25]: Stocking nest boxes with solitary bees has no captured evidence of effects on farmland wildlife.
[Statement 26]: The effectiveness of stocking nest boxes with solitary bees is unknown based on available studies.
[Statement 27]: Excluding predators can improve bee nesting outcomes.
[Statement 28]: Excluding ants from solitary bee nests increased offspring production for the bee species Exonuera nigrescens in a replicated controlled trial.
[Statement 29]: Rearing and management experience indicates several Megachilidae bee species readily nest in drilled wooden blocks or stacked grooved boards.
[Statement 30]: Under good conditions with plentiful floral resources, local populations of some bee species can increase up to six-fold in one year.
[Statement 31]: Parasites and pathogens can be problematic for bee populations in artificial nests.

[Statement 1]: Uncropped arable field margins can be sown with a native wild flower seed mix.
[Statement 2]: Replicated UK trials reported higher bumblebee abundance on field margins sown with a native wild flower seed mix than on cropped edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated margins.
[Statement 3]: The same UK trials often reported higher species richness on margins sown with a native wild flower seed mix.
[Statement 4]: Perennial leguminous herbs are important for bee forage.
[Statement 5]: Arable field margins can be left uncropped to allow for natural regeneration.
[Statement 6]: Some replicated UK trials found more foraging bumblebees and more bee species on naturally regenerated margins than on cropped margins.
[Statement 7]: The results for naturally regenerated margins varied by year and were often driven by the presence of thistles.
[Statement 8]: Grass strips can be provided at field margins.
[Statement 9]: Replicated controlled UK trials reported mixed evidence on the effectiveness of grass strips for bees.
[Statement 10]: Some UK trials showed that 6-meter grassy margins increased bumblebee abundance and sometimes diversity.
[Statement 11]: Margins or plots on farmland can be left uncropped and cultivated.
[Statement 12]: Multiple studies in the UK and Northwest Europe found that uncropped, cultivated margins or plots benefit invertebrates, including increasing bumblebee species richness.
[Statement 13]: Some studies on uncropped, cultivated margins reported neutral or mixed effects and weed issues.
[Statement 14]: A separate evidence synthesis on uncropped cultivated margins or plots reported variable butterfly outcomes across different countries and schemes.
[Statement 15]: Wildflower or nectar-flower strips, including in-field strips, can be planted on farmland.
[Statement 16]: Many studies across Europe and North America reported higher richness and/or abundance of butterflies and moths on flower strips compared to conventional margins or cropped fields.
[Statement 17]: Numerous studies showed positive invertebrate responses to flower strips in general.
[Statement 18]: Dedicated floral resources like phacelia, clovers, and lupines can be planted on farmland.
[Statement 19]: Trials in Europe and North America recorded substantial numbers and species of foraging wild bees on sown flowering patches.
[Statement 20]: Some studies noted a strong attraction of bumblebees to perennial leguminous herbs.
[Statement 21]: Specific cases have shown enhanced reproductive success for solitary bees as a result of sown flowering patches.
[Statement 22]: The agricultural landscape can be managed to enhance floral resources.
[Statement 23]: A large replicated controlled study found that the abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on margins was positively correlated with the number of ‘pollen and nectar’ agreements in the surrounding landscape.
[Statement 24]: Agri-environment schemes can be introduced to support bees.
[Statement 25]: Replicated European trials reported enhanced wild bee diversity and/or abundance on land under various agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 26]: Other trials found no enhancement for wild bees at some sites or with some agri-environment scheme options.

key: _gpt-5__On farmland, what are some alternatives to sowing uncropped field margins with agricultural nectar mixes to increase floral resources for bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Artificially created bare-soil patches were successfully colonized by ground-nesting solitary bees in the first or second year after creation.
[Statement 2]: Artificially created bare-soil patches were successfully colonized by ground-nesting solitary wasps in the first or second year after creation.
[Statement 3]: The evidence for this colonization is based on one replicated controlled trial in Germany.
[Statement 4]: The evidence for this colonization is also based on four small trials.
[Statement 5]: Three of the four small trials were replicated.
[Statement 6]: One of the four small trials was not replicated.

key: _gpt-5__What is the evidence regarding the timeframe for bee colonization of newly created nesting habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating patches of bare ground is an evidence-based intervention to improve nesting habitat for ground-nesting bees.
[Statement 2]: In multiple trials, patches of bare ground were successfully colonised by ground-nesting solitary bees and wasps within one to two years.
[Statement 3]: Reducing or eliminating tillage is an intervention for which evidence is mixed.
[Statement 4]: One study found no difference in bee abundance between tilled and untilled farms.
[Statement 5]: Another study reported that no-till farms have three times more squash bees (Peponapis pruinosa) than conventional farms.

key: _gpt-5__What interventions are available to improve nesting habitat for ground-nesting bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence on captive bumblebee rearing includes 22 trials from 13 countries which used a variety of methods.
[Statement 2]: One trial observed a gradual decrease in the weight of Bombus terrestris queens over a four-year period.
[Statement 3]: Trials on declining North American bumblebee species show mixed results for captive-rearing.
[Statement 4]: In captive-rearing trials, Bombus vagans queens successfully reared adults.
[Statement 5]: Bombus terricola and Bombus rufocinctus queens reared adults in some captive-rearing attempts.
[Statement 6]: In three trials, Bombus fervidus queens laid eggs, but the larvae died before reaching adulthood.
[Statement 7]: Larval mortality similar to that of Bombus fervidus was reported for Bombus affinis (the rusty-patched bumblebee) and Bombus pensylvanicus.
[Statement 8]: The bumblebee species Bombus ruderatus was successfully reared in captivity.
[Statement 9]: Laboratory rearing has been reported for the pocket-making bumblebee, Bombus atratus.
[Statement 10]: The performance of captive-reared bumblebees is influenced by diet and husbandry.
[Statement 11]: Using freshly frozen pollen, rather than dried frozen pollen, increased queen size and subsequent colony performance.
[Statement 12]: Providing higher-protein pollen to bumblebees increased the production of worker offspring.
[Statement 13]: An 8-hour light to 16-hour dark light regime shortened the time it took for queens to lay eggs.
[Statement 14]: Specific hibernation regimes for bumblebees affected survival and colony formation.
[Statement 15]: Hibernating queens at 4–5°C for 45 days enhanced egg-laying and colony formation but resulted in smaller colonies.
[Statement 16]: The survival likelihood for queens improved for those weighing more than 0.6 grams and for those hibernated for four months or less.
[Statement 17]: Seven replicated field trials on the reintroduction of laboratory-reared bumblebee colonies report mixed success.
[Statement 18]: In four reintroduction trials, bumblebee colonies were monitored until new queens emerged or the founding queen died.
[Statement 19]: Two reintroduction trials in the UK yielded very low or zero new queens per colony.
[Statement 20]: Two other reintroduction trials produced good numbers of new queens.
[Statement 21]: Social parasitism rates in bumblebee colonies after release were variable.
[Statement 22]: Two replicated trials, one in Canada and one in the UK, found high rates of social parasitism in released colonies.
[Statement 23]: Social parasitism was reduced by placing colonies in landscapes with intermediate floral resources rather than very high floral resources.
[Statement 24]: Social parasitism in released colonies was reduced by releasing the colonies later in the season.
[Statement 25]: Five other reintroduction trials reported no social parasites.
[Statement 26]: Supplementary feeding of reintroduced bumblebee colonies produced inconsistent benefits.
[Statement 27]: One Canadian trial showed that supplementary feeding improved reproductive success without reducing the parasite load.
[Statement 28]: A trial in the USA found that supplementary feeding did not increase colony productivity.
[Statement 29]: A small Norwegian trial found that released Bombus terrestris bumblebees foraged mostly more than 100 meters from their nests.

key: _gpt-5__What is the state of the evidence regarding the success of captive rearing and subsequent reintroduction of bumblebees into the wild?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two of four replicated European trials found that extensively managed meadows with delayed first cuts and little agrochemical use had higher wild bee numbers and diversity.
[Statement 2]: Two of four replicated European trials found no difference in wild bee numbers and diversity when comparing extensively managed meadows to conventional meadows or to those with reduced fertilizer or cutting intensity.
[Statement 3]: Evidence on the effects of reduced or no-tillage practices on ground-nesting bees is mixed.
[Statement 4]: One of two replicated trials on squash farms in the USA found no difference in bee populations between tilled and untilled farms.
[Statement 5]: One of two replicated trials on squash farms in the USA found three times more squash bees on no-till farms than on conventional farms.
[Statement 6]: A replicated trial reported that lowering summer cattle grazing intensity increased the abundance of cavity-nesting bees and wasps.
[Statement 7]: A replicated trial reported that lowering summer cattle grazing intensity did not increase the species richness of cavity-nesting bees and wasps.
[Statement 8]: In at least one study on permanent grassland management, reduced grazing intensity or seasonal livestock removal increased bee and wasp abundance.
[Statement 9]: In at least one study on permanent grassland management, reduced grazing intensity or seasonal livestock removal did not increase bee and wasp species richness.
[Statement 10]: Other studies on permanent grassland management found mixed or no benefits to invertebrates from reduced grazing or seasonal livestock removal, depending on the context.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented effects of reducing the intensity of farming practices, such as tillage, grazing, and meadow management, on wild bee populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Artificial nest sites, also known as nest boxes, can be provided for solitary bees.
[Statement 2]: In 29 out of 30 replicated trials across 10 countries, artificial nest sites were occupied by solitary bees, including endangered species.
[Statement 3]: Common effective designs for solitary bee nest boxes include bundles of cut hollow stems or tubes and wooden blocks drilled with holes.
[Statement 4]: Some wooden boxes without internal stems were used as artificial nest sites for solitary bees in Neotropical forests.
[Statement 5]: Reed stem and grooved-board designs for nest boxes produced more bees per nest than plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes.
[Statement 6]: Nest boxes made with plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes had higher instances of parasitism or mould.
[Statement 7]: In multiple agricultural studies, the repeated provision of artificial nest sites at a location resulted in the number of occupied nests doubling over three years.
[Statement 8]: A trial conducted in blueberry fields recorded increased foraging by Osmia bees in fields where nest boxes were provided.
[Statement 9]: Foraging range estimates of 150–600 meters for solitary bees suggest placing nest boxes within this distance of forage.
[Statement 10]: Parasitism and other causes of mortality in artificial nest boxes were reported across several studies.
[Statement 11]: Introduced earwigs and non-native leafcutter bees sometimes occupied artificial nest boxes.
[Statement 12]: Soil-filled boxes designed for a species of mining bee were not used.
[Statement 13]: Solitary bee nest boxes were readily used in several countries, with reported cavity occupancy rates between 1% and 26%.
[Statement 14]: The provision of nest boxes for solitary bees has led to increases in local population size or the number of emerging red mason bees.
[Statement 15]: The highest production of solitary bees was found in nest boxes made from reed stems or wood materials.
[Statement 16]: Multiple designs for artificial bumblebee nest sites have been tested, including surface, underground, and aerial or tree-attached boxes.
[Statement 17]: Underground, false underground, or aerial boxes for bumblebees are more readily occupied than wooden surface boxes.
[Statement 18]: Entirely buried bumblebee boxes, placed 5–10 cm deep with a 30–80 cm entrance pipe, showed 6–58% occupancy.
[Statement 19]: Recent UK trials of surface nest boxes for bumblebees showed very low uptake of 0–2.5%.
[Statement 20]: Several earlier trials of surface nest boxes for bumblebees in the UK, USA, and Canada reported 10–48% uptake.
[Statement 21]: No evidence was found that providing artificial nest sites affects bumblebee populations.
[Statement 22]: Two separate bumblebee nest box trials recorded very low uptake of 2% or less.
[Statement 23]: No evidence was found for the effects on farmland wildlife from introducing nest boxes stocked with solitary bees.

key: _gpt-5__What actions, other than providing bare ground, can be taken to create or enhance nesting sites for various bee species?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Available actions to provide nesting resources for bees include providing artificial nest sites for solitary bees and installing bee nest boxes for solitary bees or bumblebees.
[Statement 2]: Solitary bee nest boxes are readily used across many regions and species.
[Statement 3]: Occupancy has been reported in most trials of solitary bee nest boxes.
[Statement 4]: Between 1–26% of available cavities in solitary bee nest boxes were reported as occupied.
[Statement 5]: Between 4.6 and 33 species have been recorded using solitary bee nest boxes.
[Statement 6]: On agricultural land, repeated provision of solitary bee nest boxes at the same site can nearly double the number of occupied nests over three years.
[Statement 7]: Increases in foraging Osmia bees were observed in blueberry fields with nest boxes compared to fields without nest boxes.
[Statement 8]: Recommended design and placement details for bee nest boxes include situating the boxes within 150–600 meters of forage resources.
[Statement 9]: Recommended nesting materials for bee nest boxes include reed stems or wood/grooved boards.
[Statement 10]: Nesting materials such as reed stems or wood/grooved boards produced more bees per nest than several alternatives.
[Statement 11]: Plastic-lined or plastic/paper tubes were less productive as nesting materials due to parasitism or mould.
[Statement 12]: Bumblebee nest boxes have a very low uptake of around 2% or less in replicated trials.
[Statement 13]: Potential issues with bee nest boxes include parasitism and predation on the bees inside them.
[Statement 14]: Reported mortality and parasitism of bees in nest boxes vary by context.

key: _gpt-5__What actions are available to provide nesting resources for bees on agricultural land?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: At the local patch scale, sown flower patches on farmland attract substantial numbers of foraging wild bees, especially bumblebees.
[Statement 2]: Observed wild bee species counts on phacelia-rich patches have ranged from 8 to 35.
[Statement 3]: The attractiveness of sown flower patches to wild bees can vary by region and has been observed to be lower in Greece.
[Statement 4]: Patch-scale interventions for bees have shown mixed evidence for broader population responses.
[Statement 5]: One trial found that planted lupine patches in apple orchards significantly enhanced the reproductive success of the bee species Osmia lignaria.
[Statement 6]: Another trial found bee numbers and species richness in farmland 50–1,500 meters away from planted patches were not higher.
[Statement 7]: Two trials reported no or relatively few solitary bees nesting on set-aside fields sown with phacelia or clover.
[Statement 8]: Field margins sown with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes attract significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped margins.
[Statement 9]: Perennial leguminous plants are particularly effective at attracting foraging bumblebees when sown in field margins.
[Statement 10]: The value of sown field margins for attracting bumblebees may degrade over time and require re-sowing every few years.
[Statement 11]: At the wider landscape scale, one large trial found that the average abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on field margins was positively correlated with the number of ‘pollen and nectar’ agri-environment agreements within a 10 km grid square.
[Statement 12]: The attractiveness of planted perennial leguminous herbs to bumblebees increased in landscapes with a greater proportion of arable farming.
[Statement 13]: Landscape context can influence the outcomes of patch-level floral resource plantings.

key: _gpt-5__How do the impacts of planting floral resources for bees differ when implemented at a local patch scale versus a wider landscape scale?
